COMMON.NAME: Asian Emerald Dove
SPECIES.COMMENTS: Today morning I saw this Emerald Dove fly straight into a glass window of a school building and collapse into the ground. It succumbed to the injuries sustained as a result of banging into the glass pane and died within a few minutes. Everything happened so suddenly. It was painful to see a bird die like this..Sadly so many birds die each year as a result of striking into glass panes.. After the collision it flew bizarrely for a few seconds and then collapsed to the ground. It tried digging its head in the undergrowth for a little while and then lay still with its head buried in the undergrowth. I didn't try to revive it as I didn't know how to. Moreover I was too shocked as the whole incident happened very suddenly.

COMMON.NAME: Asian Emerald Dove
SPECIES.COMMENTS: 1 female (out of the pair) unfortunately dashed on the transparent glass of the vehicle in front of us.....the impact proved fatal. This is one of the many instances I have witnessed with Emerald Doves and Oriental Dwarf Kingfishers all over Western Ghats where they dash on the glass or mirror, thinking that it is a gap between the undergrowth..... both these species are known to fly in break-neck speeds through the gaps in undergrowth.

COMMON.NAME: Black-backed Dwarf-Kingfisher
SPECIES.COMMENTS: Dashed into Tea pantry and got confused, while trying to escape hit into glass windows again and again. Unable to fly - rescued and later released after an hour. Flew for few metres and fell down. Again rescued back, fed water - kept in observations. Again released in the evening - flew into the forest and disappears.

COMMON.NAME: Black-backed Dwarf-Kingfisher
SPECIES.COMMENTS: Hello! We found a dead Oriental dwarf kingfisher in our building in Chembur, Bombay! It's really so sad, read only yesterday that they had arrived from Sri Lanka to Karnala bird sanctuary. Can any one help me to understand if this bird can be preserved or given to any foundation for research? Hello everyone! The bird has been given to Omkar Adhikari at BNHS he spoke to me and told me that the bird is in a very good condition and shows no signs of injury so seems to be a natural death. They want to taxidermy it so they will keep me posted. They were very helpful and communicative though they did say that bird collection happens in their goregaon office but as an exception received it at their colaba office

COMMON.NAME: Black-backed Dwarf-Kingfisher
SPECIES.COMMENTS: This bird came and hit into my wall, it was injure and then i took it to my room. it was kept about an hour to regain its strength and later was released back in the stream nearby behind my house.

COMMON.NAME: Black-backed Dwarf-Kingfisher

Oneday they showed me the pic and i got intrested to see that it was oriental dwarf kingfisher. Very intresting to see in that location near by paddy field and others are laterite rocky areas with patches of forest. And ofcourse there are good patches of forest which are few km from this location.

COMMON.NAME: Black-backed Dwarf-Kingfisher
SPECIES.COMMENTS: This is a successful bird rescue incident. The bird crashed into a hospital window and found in a disoriented condition at Mapusa on 25th October at 7AM. It was then taken to Porvorim for treatment for neuro trauma and was successfully treated with Meloxicam and Neurobion for 48 hours with rehydrants and forced fish feeding. It recovered very well and was released on 27th October in a habitat consistent with the species of the bird at Socorro in a deep forested gorge with ample of fish and water.

COMMON.NAME: Black-backed Dwarf-Kingfisher
SPECIES.COMMENTS: Got informed about an injured bird from a Local Person.one of us went there and collected the bird.bird was not able to fly so we keep it under observation for one day and released at a nearby place in the Evening

COMMON.NAME: Black Kite
SPECIES.COMMENTS: This black kite juvenile hit the door of my hall. We ran to see what the big noise was about and saw it lying on the floor. It was not in itâ€™s senses then. I ran inside to get my camera and took itâ€™s pic to put here in case I needed some guidance. --I sat beside it to check and saw itâ€™s heart thumping. I was a little relieved to see it alive. After sometime it opened itâ€™s eyes and looked at me. It got up and flew towards the parking area in my compound.--There it sat in a corner. I thought it was scared of me but later saw 6 birds angrily making noise. 2 drongos, 2 bulbuls and 2 jungle babblers were sitting just near by. Then the drongo suddenly flew towards the kite to attack it even when I was still standing near it. --The kite after a while flew away still followed by the agitated birds who were still attacking it.  Have the pics too!!!

COMMON.NAME: Bluethroat
SPECIES.COMMENTS: A migratory Bluethroat crashed into a window of a house near Chandigarh, India. It recovered and was let off in the nearby scrublands. But why do birds crash into reflective surfaces? Award-winning ornithologist KS Gopi Sundar explains why and fears this may increase as more and more buildings are displaying such reflective surfaces. (Pix by Nitin Sarin of the Bluethroat that crashed into a window)The Sunday `wildbuzz' column in HT.

COMMON.NAME: Indian Pitta
SPECIES.COMMENTS: I too came across a dead pitta in middle of city in Delhi. According to some people it was dead for at least a couple of hours. Later understood that Pitta's which are known to migrate to North India for breeding during rainy season, return back around November. Many of us would get surprises if we see indian pitta by mistake in our neighborhood during this migration. The reason for the dead pitta might lie in the fact that sometimes birds tend to fight with their own reflection when the come across glazed mirrors. In my case, the building outside which it was found was the same. So birds would hit the reflection on the glass and injured themselves... Unfortunately leaving them helpless

But didn't kept for long. Released as soon as we got it in the coconut groove. Was hopping around for sometime and we left that place after sometime. Don't know what happened to this bird.

COMMON.NAME: Malabar Whistling-Thrush
SPECIES.COMMENTS: November 2018 - Valparai, Tamilnadu. Day 1 @Valparai Bungalow-There was this little shiny bird which by mistake had entered a room full of glass windows. It repeatedly flew and hit the glass and was not able to find its way out.Once it hit the glass window and fell down. I sat on the floor, touched the bird,to soothe it, and slowly crawled on the ground. The bird limped and followed me. Once it came out it flew. Day 2- The next evening,I was sipping my tea. Its boyfriend came whistled, danced infront of me as a sign of gratitude. It spent almost 20 minutes very close to me. #story #thrush #songbirds #malabar #schoolboy #beautifulbirds

COMMON.NAME: Scaly-breasted Munia
SPECIES.COMMENTS: Scaly breasted Munia@Bangalore, Sept-12 A fruitful day A pair of Scaly breasted Munias were nesting in my office premises. This pair made a nest on the top of a leaf of palm tree, which was well exposed to heavy rains of Bangalore. Each day they would carry dried leaves to make the nest. Watching the tireless parents working all day was very entertaining. The nest was occupied by demanding chicks which kept calling all through the day to draw the attention of their parents. To my surprise, yesterday i couldn't see any activity of the parents. As I was moving through the corridors of my office I saw this poor bird lying motionless. I couldn't ascertain the exact cause of this tragedy, I guess it cud have smashed on to the glass panes on seeing its image. I approached it cautiously and saw it's eyes were closed, luckily it was breathing. I put some water near it, but it still didn't respond, I took the bird in my hand and felt it's feeble shaking. I poured water in the other hand, and when the bird opened it's mouth i brought my hand having water closer to its mouth and later left it on the ground which had thick growth of grass. It was late in the evening nearly 2hrs later, i approached it, it's eyes were still closed & was breathing. i gently touched it, it flew past me and perched on a nearby bush. I was glad it cud regain the strength to fly again, but i was still worried whether it would be able to fly to the nest again and feed the chicks. And the following day i cud see both the parent flying again feeding the young ones in the nest.

COMMON.NAME: Scaly-breasted Munia
SPECIES.COMMENTS: i had a similar incident with the SBM. It was trying flythrough my flat and crashed into the glass. it lay stunned and lifeless till it recovered after it was given water to drink and a light watery dab on its beak, eyes, head and neck. My profile picture shows it perched on my palm later

COMMON.NAME: Scaly-breasted Munia
SPECIES.COMMENTS:
Collied on a glass window, Subadult munia presented with inability to fly
Suspected for head trauma.

COMMON.NAME: Shikra
SPECIES.COMMENTS: This black kite juvenile hit the door of my hall. We ran to see what the big noise was about and saw it lying on the floor. It was not in it’s senses then. I ran inside to get my camera and took it’s pic to put here in case I needed some guidance. I sat beside it to check and saw it’s heart thumping. I was a little relieved to see it alive. After sometime it opened it’s eyes and looked at me. It got up and flew towards the parking area in my compound. There it sat in a corner. I thought it was scared of me but later saw 6 birds angrily making noise. 2 drongos, 2 bulbuls and 2 jungle babblers were sitting just near by. Then the drongo suddenly flew towards the kite to attack it even when I was still standing near it. The kite after a while flew away still followed by the agitated birds who were still attacking it.

COMMON.NAME: Shikra
SPECIES.COMMENTS: Had a really surprising encounter with a Shikra today!! I was inside the college library with my friends for an official photoshoot in the afternoon and suddenly saw this bird of prey fly out of nowhere in front of me! It tried flying out of the library but ended up colliding with one of the glass panels. The bird fell to the ground with a loud thud. I along with a few friends rushed to see the fallen raptor and was relieved to find that it had not suffered any head trauma and neither had broken any of its wings. It was one hell of a collision!!! I was told after a while that the Shikra had flown away. Here is a pic of the Shikra before we left it on the terrace.

COMMON.NAME: Siberian Rubythroat

COMMON.NAME: White-throated Kingfisher
SPECIES.COMMENTS: Mesmerising Even At Death, At about noon, mom heard a thud from the tall glass window near our living room. It sounded like something had hit the widow pane. This is an usual event because common cuckoos hit the window pane often. It seems they do not recognise the presence of glass. Expecting it to be a cuckoo, she ran out. But to her surprise, it was an adult White-throated Kingfisher.
